body: Solved by #4408
- [ ] Multi-Input Support

@formath For the case of RNN with variable sequence length, the support is via masking or indicating the sequence length. For example, the loss layer support `ignore_label`, which you can use to ignore parts of the tails in each sequence in your mini batch. Other RNN operators also takes something like `seq_len` to indicate the exact sequence length of each sample.

It is true that you need to pad all sequence to be the same (maximum) length in a minibatch, and the tails will be discarded. This is why we need bucketing to avoid too huge wasting when some sequences might be very long.

IMHO 1 (small circle) and 5 (loop) look best. 1 is elegant. 5 is cute (the loop around 'net' looks like a fish, so it's a fish catching a net ...). it's also probably the most recognizable and unique.
Could you explain a little more?

@jinxuan777  when i run the demo of lstm_ocr.py with mxnet, i am also meet this problem  self.draw.draw_arc(xy, start, end, ink), TypeError: must be sequence of length 4, not 2 
i try all the ways in this content, but i do not slove this problem, would you help me fix this problem? thanks

@piiswrong , The problem is sym_w and sym_b are not input data. Thus, the data_iter can not provide their shapes and types explicitly when creating the corresponding mx.sym.Module. It will cause an error if I execute module.fit afterwards.
For instance, the code is like
```
data_iter = xxx # provide_data=[('data', data_shape)], provide_label=[('label', label_shape)]
mod = mx.sym.Module(data_names=('data', ), label_names=('label',), context=mx.gpu())
mod.bind(data_shapes=data_iter.provide_data, label_shapes=data_iter.provide_label)
mod.init_params(xxx)
mod.init_optimizer(xxx)
mod.fit(xxx)
```
This should work with the nnvm branch
@formath I have tried it, I found that if I used 2 buckets ,only one bucket updated during training and the other stayed the same.

vote 4.
Shows mix, and that's the key feature of mxnet, isn't it?

ImportError: cannot import name libinfo        

can you have any idea to solve it ?
Thank you very much!

The original code makes the assumption on dev_type is only CPU and GPU. The corresponding value is 0 and 1. so the code use the value to calculate the offset.

Unfortunately, the assumption is wrong. CPUPinned is 3. the result of offset is wrong that caused segment fatal.

Since dev_type is a enum, I put a switch to explicit about the intention. Assume the value of enum is bad programming habit.

The crash can be repo (100%) via train ssd with 2 GPUs. I notice this crash when debug SSD example.

I don't have number on IO. SSD with one single GPU in my box (GTX1070), the speed is increasing from 18samples/sec to 38samples/sec.

I used the profiler to check. the major of time is spending in flip function in data iterator.

However this still doesn't solve two GPUs scale problem. when I added one more GPU (GTX970), the speed is around 36 sampels/sec. I am still profiling it.

You need add /opt/openblas/lib to your LD path. you can search internet for "Linux ldconfig"

or a simper solution, copy libopenblas.* from /opt/openblas/lib/ to /usr/local/lib64 (maybe /usr/local/lib) depends on your env. i don't have centos to check for sure.) after copy, run the command to refresh ld cacahe: "sudo ldconfig"

use nvidia-smi

Also the author of SSD updated his paper and proposed a new network structure (use more conv layers) and some additional data augments. Shall I update this SSD sample? the challenge is how to maintain back compatibility?

For example, the inner_product_layer and batch_norm_layer have different initialization methods, how to ensure proper initialization by using mxnet's initializers?  I'm sorry that I'm not familiar with mxnet code.
A random thought, since data loading is so critial to performance, shall we also move data iterator under execute engine?

@piiswrong, OK, I will have a try.
By the way, are there any differences between nnvm and master for an up-level user? Will the nnvm branch become the master branch someday?

WRT NNPACK, there are a few useful patches for NNPACK (non-MXNet specific) we'll PR shortly:

1) Improve multithreaded performance via a pthreadpool rewrite.
2) Improve 3x3 convolutions via dedicated NEON impl.

Those improve performance vs im2col/sgemm performance (even at batch-size=1 and small channel sizes) pretty significantly.
NNPACK in MXNet now is very limited, please try this pr: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/4373 i have test it on PC, which will speed 2x~7x. thansk.  @ydmo
@nicklhy  merged just now! for users,  there is almost no difference, but for develops, nnvm branch will be more convenience to write c++ code, such as operation.

+    networks = ['resnet-50']
+    devs = [] # [mx.gpu(0)] if len(get_gpus()) > 0 else
     # Enable USE_MKL2017_EXPERIMENTAL for better CPU performance
     devs.append(mx.cpu())
 
-    batch_sizes = [1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32]
+    batch_sizes = [ 16,32]
 
     for net in networks:
         logging.info('network: %s', net)

@morningpig917 Dose Compact Bilinear Pooling progress well? Any release?

@ydmo I believe the problem is that the model in Leliana/WhatsThis is incompatible with the current state of mxnet amalgamation.  Re-amalgamate and replace the `params` and `symbol.json` with those from [Squeezenet v1.1](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet-model-gallery/blob/master/imagenet-1k-squeezenet.md) and it should work.
@sun9700 You can check my fork. I have implemented FFT, IFFT and count-sketch operators. But the count sketch seems not efficient enough, so I have not PR it.
Nop, we don't expose cuda APIs in python side. You might need to write your own API or call nvidia-smi in python and parse the output as the above suggested.

My OS is Mac OS sierra 10.12.1 and my graphics card is Intel Iris Pro 1536 MB so I am not sure it actually supports CUDA or not

Try to use following settings in config.mk:

USE_BLAS = openblas
ADD_CFLAGS += -I/usr/local/opt/openblas/include
ADD_LDFLAGS += -L/usr/local/opt/openblas/lib
ADD_LDFLAGS += -L/usr/local/lib/graphviz/
USE_CUDA = 1
USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda
USE_CUDNN = 1
USE_NVRTC = 1

http://mxnet.io/api/r/mxnet-r-reference-manual.pdf
@mli @tqchen Any ideas? It doesn't seem to be building properly

build log is here: http://mxnet.io:8080/job/mxnet/312/console

btw, we should also host document for previous releases.

No bucketing is not for this problem. I'm not sure what would be a better way to handle this (and I'm not even sure if deep networks will work better in this case than traditional methods). One way is always to convert that to dense vectors, and use smaller mini-batch. That is of course very wasteful. Maybe one can implement some custom layer like the `Embedding` layer, that could handle sparse vector with multiple non-zeros (instead of only one non-zero entry).

does this install jenkins?

No, this itself doesn't build Jenkins. This is for Jenkins to set up build slaves. 

The Dockerfile is the build slave image, the test script will be called as a build step in Jenkins.

Hi Eric:
   This is the case that could not cover, it is only for "fwd_filter_data   @ MKLConvolutionOp"
  MXImperativeInvoke is call directly from c_api
int MXImperativeInvoke(AtomicSymbolCreator creator,
                       int num_inputs,
                       NDArrayHandle *inputs,
                       int *num_outputs,
                       NDArrayHandle **outputs,
                       int num_params,
                       const char **param_keys,
                       const char **param_vals)
